body: BTW I also made a minor change to put new manifests at the beginning of the manifest list to be consistent with the other snapshot producers

+1

This is a little different because we're storing the whole visitor instance as a thread local as opposed to just the internal state, but that's effectively the same.  LGTM.

Yes, thanks for pointing it out!

Benefit of being able to use relative paths in snapshots and manifests is that tables can be migrated to different File System / warehouse namespaces without having to re-write iceberg metadata. /cc @rominparekh  @fbocse
@edgarRd, is it possible to separate out the listPartition support? It seems like that could go in earlier while we review the metrics support.
@rdblue I just pushed https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/210 for listPartition support - I'll rebase this PR from master once that gets merged.

@aokolnychyi, I think we should fix the write format option to be shorter (in a separate PR). That format works for table properties, but isn't good for options that users have to remember. We should change it to `write-format`?
Build is failing - is this ready for review as a standalone item or did you want to do more here? What's next for this feature moving forward?

Merged. Thanks for contributing this, @bryanck!

And thanks for reviewing this, @aokolnychyi and @danielcweeks!
@rdsr, this looks fine to me, but could you update the description with the reason for changing this? Is it to make the converters reusable?
I found a couple of minor problems, but overall it looks good. Once the last couple things are fixed, I'll merge it. Thanks for working on this!
@edgarRd, I merged #210 so you can rebase. Thanks!
Yes, It is to not create the converter DAG per record reading. I'll update
See more in #61.
Thanks, @rdblue! Yeah, I do agree on aligning other properties with the style proposed in this PR.

> Dictionaries are part of the Arrow Schema definition, but should be built based off the parquet dictionaries. 

@danielcweeks This actually changed in Arrow master as it lead to a lot of problems. With the changes in Arrow master, reading rowgroups with Dictionaries should be much simpler.
I'll submit a PR soon
@mccheah We're going to start investing in building out the arrow read path starting in a couple weeks, so I'll try to address the checkstyle issues and we'll build on this from there.
Merged. Thanks for reviewing, @aokolnychyi!

Just want to leave an update on this. I think that there is probably a better approach than adding a new method to `Table`. I'm waiting on getting the new catalog implementation in to submit a PR.

I also agree that there should be a comment in MetadataTableScan to explain the record names.
@rdblue how do we fetch `columnSizes` now? Is it supposed to be for internal use only?
@rdblue in light of recent changes, am I correct that this PR is about `value_counts`, `null_value_counts`, `lower_bounds`, `upper_bounds` only?
@mccheah @rdblue @rdsr don't we need to discard `iceberg.hadoop.` and not `iceberg.hadoop`?
@aokolnychyi rebased, thank you for the heads-up
I'd merge this since there are only nits, but it conflicts with the baseline patch I just merged. Could you rebase and update?
@aokolnychyi, yes. Want to open a PR?
@aokolnychyi, I think that sounds good.
@aokolnychyi, you can load column sizes by calling `includeColumnStats`. Looks like it also needs to be in the list of stats in `FilteredManifest` as well. I think that's a bug.
@omalley FYI

Thanks @rdblue  for the comments. I wanted to get a sense from you for the overall approach here, specifically around the mapping , where the fieldname to id map contains non canonical field names and testing strategy. Do you think the current approach is sound enough?
Yeah, will do so.
@rdblue, exactly. By calling `includeColumnStats` we cannot fetch `columnSizes` as of now.
I think this also needs to update the `length` javadoc because the requirement that the appender has been closed is no longer needed.

> I think this also needs to update the `length` javadoc because the requirement that the appender has been closed is no longer needed.

Good spot.  I've updated the javadoc.

Here's the problem:

```
[ant:checkstyle] [ERROR] /home/travis/build/apache/incubator-iceberg/core/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/avro/AvroFileAppender.java:22:8: Unused import - com.google.common.base.Preconditions. [UnusedImports]
```

@rdblue ,  as per the spec 
> The source column, selected by id, must be a primitive type and cannot be contained in a map or list, but may be nested in a struct

So we can possibly have 2 ways to address this. 
1. Automatically replace the dot with underscore
2. Allow user to specify the target column name in the partition field
Iceberg supports special characters in names, looks like the failure is in Avro. I think Iceberg should sanitize special characters from the names when creating an Avro schema.

The special char can only be DOT though right?
Also it seems like you are suggesting that we should handle the sanitization in TypeToSchema visitor. That makes sense to me.

I think it could be anything since we allow users to pass strings into `UpdateSchema`. We should probably sanitize any character that isn't allowed by Avro, assuming that they might creep in.

By the way, because we project based on ID and not by name, the names used in Avro files don't really matter. So this should be safe to change.
I have a preliminary fix for this issue in branch: https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/compare/master...edgarRd:orc-column-map-fix
@danielcweeks @rdblue shall we update `ReplaceManifests` to use `length` instead of estimating the size of each entry?
@aokolnychyi Excellent observation! Yes, we should switch the estimate over to use the length (@bryanck, FYI)
Nice! I'll create a PR for this.
+1, I'll merge when tests pass.

@rdblue while we have `as-of-timestamp`, `snapshot-id`, users can still set Hadoop conf via `iceberg.hadoop` (e.g. `iceberg.hadoop.iceberg.compress.metadata`).

Do we want to keep that as is?

@aokolnychyi, I think it would make sense to simplify it to just `hadoop.(hadoop option)`.

@mccheah FYI.
@rdblue makes sense to me, shall it be in this PR?
That makes sense to me.
Thanks for logging this @prodeezy . I will work on this and raise a PR for it.
I've updated the way we process Hadoop options as well.
@rdblue @danielcweeks what do you think guys?
+1, thanks for fixing this, @aokolnychyi!
Merged. Thanks for reviewing, @rdsr!
@aokolnychyi, this looks great. Overall, I had just one issue with the idempotent check. Thanks for contributing this!

> Ive changed UTF8 to Utf8 because Baseline required this.

Can we disable this rule? I don't think it is valuable and it requires a lot of code changes that result in awkward names, like Utf8Reader.

I tried to add `UTF8` to the list of allowed abbreviations but it didn't work for me (it worked for `SQL`, though). I will disable this rule in the next pass. Let me know what you think about the other open questions.
@rdsr @mccheah @rdblue Shall we close this one?
@rdsr @mccheah @rdblue Shall we close this one?
cc @rdsr @mccheah

+1. 

I'll get a PR going for this (the intellij support for iceberg is buggy for this project. It picks up an older version of guava and doesn't find symbol for toStringHelper)

@rdblue How do you see it in 2.4? I understand that `HiveTables` will be used when no path is given but how will we fetch the table identifier? As another data source property?

Also, how will it look like when we have support for `CREATE TABLE` statements, where `LOCATION` says if it is a managed or external table?
I was planning on adding support by inspecting the path. If it contains `/`, then it is a path and should use HadoopTables. If it doesn't, then use it as a table identifier with HiveTables.
Thank you @SurenNihalani!

Nice work, @edgarRd! I think this is pretty close. Eventually, I'd also like to apply some of the schema tests that we use for Parquet and Avro to ORC to validate that all projections work. Seems like a good follow-up.

Could you also document the serialization format for the column map, and what property you're using? I'd like to include this in the spec.

@rdblue , @edgarRd . I was thinking about this and wanted to get your inputs here. 

I was thinking if the implementation would become simpler/cleaner if we maintained the column ids close to the ORC schema. For instance, we could do something similar to Avro schema, where the column ids are maintained as metadata properties tied to each schema element. This, of course, is not possible today with ORC's `TypeDescription`. But, let's say we exposed a `RichTypeDescription` schema for ORC instead of its standard `TypeDescription`. The `RichTypeDescription` would maintain metadata properties for each schema field, similar to Avro. This metadata property will hold the column ids. This could help get rid of the separate map which we have to maintain, can possibly also make things simpler when we have to address schema evolution [by id] during read where we'd have to make use of visitors, similar to Avro. 

The big benefit I see is that we don't have to expose two data structures or spread the schema information across two classes.  

Another potential benefit of this approach is, if we can get the ORC community to adopt a patch which attaches  metadata per field, then we can completely get rid of our own `RichTypeDescription` without changing our code drastically.
Thanks for fixing this, @electrum! I didn't realize we accidentally used commons-io.

@rdsr, are you proposing that we attach an alternative schema to a data file? If so, why not just write the JSON form of the Iceberg schema? I like the idea to get changes we need into upstream ORC (@omalley may be able to help there) but I think we should get this working before those are written, committed, and released.
@danielcweeks, when you have time could you review this?

I had some minor comments, but I don't see any bugs introduced by this. Thanks @aokolnychyi!

I think the choices you made sound good.
@edgarRd, is this ready for another round of reviews, or should we merge #227 first?

> are you proposing that we attach an alternative schema to a data file? If so, why not just write the JSON form of the Iceberg schema?

The mechanism to persist field ids could be anything depending on our implementation, which would be neatly encapsulated in the ORC class. Today, we are serializing a  Map, we could just as well serialize a json as you mentioned.  But the schema class that we construct should have the field ids [as described above]. I'm just curious whether having a single schema class with ids instead of a Map and a schema class would make future and current changes simpler.

I'm also totally fine by first trying to fix ORC first before we make any changes here.

I've removed `AbbreviationAsWordInName` and reverted changes required by that rule.

Also, the PR description contains a few points I want to bring attention on Scala formatting in Baseline. Let me know if we want to change defaults there.
LGTM. @rdblue what do you think?

Here are some responses to the questions in the description. The rest of them sound fine to me.

> Baseline applies ReturnChecker. Is it ok for us?

Yes? What does it do?

> Baseline doesn't apply ImportOrderChecker by default. Shall we add it?

Yes, I think so.

> Baseline doesn't apply DisallowSpaceBeforeTokenChecker by default. Shall we add it?

I think so. This is consistent with the Java formatting, right?

> Baseline doesn't apply NonASCIICharacterChecker by default. Shall we add it?

Is this intended to catch fancy quotes? I think we probably don't need it. Plus, we have some areas with multi-byte characters in strings (@rdsr's recent Avro fix, for example).

+1

@electrum, the validation failure is caused by extra newlines in imports. I'll merge once this is passing checkstyle.
Hi @rdblue , please have a look when u get the time. I've addressed your remaining comments. I need your inputs specifically on some of the TODOs I've added to the code.
Thanks, I need to update my IntelliJ config for this project.
@rdblue yeah, I was thinking in getting #227 to have the correct column mapping.
